title: 107_s930
content:
The Grand Canyon Capital Improvements Act of 2001 establishes definitions for terms like fundraising organization, memorandum of agreement, Park, and Secretary. It also outlines the creation of a fundraising organization and the use of bond proceeds for improvements in the Grand Canyon National Park. The Secretary may enter into a memorandum of agreement with a fundraising organization to issue taxable bonds for the Park, subject to professional standards and audits. The United States is not liable for the organization's bonds. The fundraising organization must enter a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue amount, maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, funded projects at the Park, responsibilities of the Secretary and organization for each project, and procedures for agreement modifications. The Secretary may authorize the Superintendent of the Park to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under various programs. The fundraising organization can charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under certain programs. This surcharge must be used to amortize bond issues, cover administration costs, and maintain a reserve as determined by the bond underwriter. SEC. 6. USE OF BOND PROCEEDS.

Bond proceeds can be used for projects in the Park, subject to certain limitations. Projects must align with laws governing the National Park System, Park laws, and the Park's general management plan. No bond proceeds can be used for administrative expenses, except for interest. Interest earned can be used for reserve requirements and reasonable administrative expenses related to bond management and sale. SEC. 7. REPORT.

The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of regulations being issued under section 8, reviewing the bond program at the Park and providing recommendations on establishing a bond program at all National Park System units.

SEC. 8. REGULATIONS.

The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Treasury, will issue regulations to implement this Act.
